articles.headline: Inevitability of a Default in Greece
articles.snippet: Europe needs to act to keep a Greek default from destroying its financial system, then accept the reality.
articles.abstract: Europe needs to act to keep a Greek default from destroying its financial system, then accept the reality.
articles.lead_paragraph: A Greek debt restructuring — a polite term for default — is unthinkable, according to the Greek finance minister.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Rethinking Bid to Overhaul Medicare Rules
articles.snippet: The decision to pull back shows the difficulties involved in trying to address the nation’s long-term fiscal problems.
articles.abstract: The decision to pull back shows the difficulties involved in trying to address the nation’s long-term fiscal problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republicans signaled Thursday that they were backing away from the centerpiece of their budget plan — a proposal to overhaul Medicare — in a decision that underscored both the difficulties and political perils of addressing the nation’s long-term fiscal problems.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and Jackie Calmes

articles.headline: Data Show Bin Laden Plots; C.I.A. Hid Near Raided House
articles.snippet: Seized documents prompted U.S. officials to issue a warning that Al Qaeda had considered attacks on U.S. railroads. The C.I.A. also had Bin Laden’s compound under surveillance.
articles.abstract: Seized documents prompted U.S. officials to issue a warning that Al Qaeda had considered attacks on U.S. railroads. The C.I.A. also had Bin Laden’s compound under surveillance.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After reviewing computer files and documents seized at the compound where Osama bin Laden was killed, American intelligence analysts have concluded that the chief of Al Qaeda played a direct role for years in plotting terror attacks from his hide-out in Abbottabad, Pakistan, United States officials said Thursday.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Scott Shane

articles.headline: At Last, a Reason to Be Always the Bridesmaid
articles.snippet: Fashion companies leapt into action to copy Kate Middleton’s wedding gown, but surprisingly, customers want copies of the bridesmaid’s gown, too.
articles.abstract: Fashion companies leapt into action to copy Kate Middleton’s wedding gown, but surprisingly, customers want copies of the bridesmaid’s gown, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shortly before the start of the royal wedding last Friday, designers and bridal boutiques planning knockoff dresses went into action when they got their first glimpse of the gown.

articles.headline: Companies Hedge Bets at a Cost to Consumers
articles.snippet: For reasons not well understood, commodities have become more volatile, increasing the costs of the futures and options that protect companies against such changes.
articles.abstract: For reasons not well understood, commodities have become more volatile, increasing the costs of the futures and options that protect companies against such changes.
articles.lead_paragraph: The extreme volatility of commodities prices and the unpredictability that comes with it is increasing the cost of doing business for everyone.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and William Neuman

articles.headline: Ending Run, Investors Abandon Commodities
articles.snippet: Fear of an economic slowdown in the United States and the rest of the world pushes down prices for commodities like oil, sugar, coffee and silver.
articles.abstract: Fear of an economic slowdown in the United States and the rest of the world pushes down prices for commodities like oil, sugar, coffee and silver.
articles.lead_paragraph: Commodities prices fell sharply on Thursday, led by the steepest drop in oil prices since the fall of 2008.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Foes Revise Plan to Curb New Agency
articles.snippet: Republicans are fighting the planned Consumer Financial Protection Bureau through oversight and budget proposals.
articles.abstract: Republicans are fighting the planned Consumer Financial Protection Bureau through oversight and budget proposals.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After losing a contentious battle last year over creating an agency to protect consumers against deceptive financial products, Republicans are fighting the battle again, determined to rein in the independence and financing of the agency.
articles.byline: By Edward Wyatt and Ben Protess

articles.headline: In Long Pursuit of Bin Laden, the ’07 Raid, and Frustration
articles.snippet: A 2007 raid in Afghanistan that could have been former President George W. Bush’s last chance to capture or kill Osama Bin Laden did not materialize.
articles.abstract: A 2007 raid in Afghanistan that could have been former President George W. Bush’s last chance to capture or kill Osama Bin Laden did not materialize.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Before Sunday, the last time an American president thought he had Osama bin Laden in his sights was the late summer of 2007.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Head of MTV Networks Resigns Abruptly
articles.snippet: Several executives said that Judy McGrath had been put into a position to resign after she received an offer that would have changed her duties.
articles.abstract: Several executives said that Judy McGrath had been put into a position to resign after she received an offer that would have changed her duties.
articles.lead_paragraph: MTV Networks, the powerhouse cable television operation behind hits like “Jersey Shore,” “SpongeBob SquarePants” and “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart,” announced on Thursday that Judy McGrath, its chairwoman and chief executive, was resigning effective immediately.

articles.headline: Raid Account, Hastily Told, Proves Fluid
articles.snippet: The shifting narrative of the raid of Osama bin Laden’s may have distracted from the accomplishments of the Seal team and raised suspicions of the operation.
articles.abstract: The shifting narrative of the raid of Osama bin Laden’s may have distracted from the accomplishments of the Seal team and raised suspicions of the operation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On Monday, the Obama administration said that Osama bin Laden had been killed after a firefight with Navy Seal commandos, and that he had used his wife as a human shield. On Tuesday, the administration said that Bin Laden was not armed at all, and that his wife had not been a shield, but had rushed her husband’s assaulter and was shot in the leg.

articles.headline: Payrolls Show Strong Growth but Jobless Rate Rises
articles.snippet: The private sector powered a gain in jobs but the unemployment rate actually nudged up to 9 percent, from 8.8 percent.
articles.abstract: The private sector powered a gain in jobs but the unemployment rate actually nudged up to 9 percent, from 8.8 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: For three straight months, the nation’s employers have delivered solid job growth, easing some concerns that the economy could be stalling.
